title: Harvest Programme

author: Nicola Cancedda, Xerox Research Centre Europe, Xerox
Marko Grobelnik, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: OK, so you've heard Speaking of this harvest program a few times in the last two days, so this presentation is about it.
Hopefully at the end of it you will know everything that you need to know.
So this is just.
The harvest program in a nutshell.
In one slide.
What is it about?
It's about funding short projects of up to average duration, about three months carried out by pins mixed between academia and industry.
So about 6 persons or so.
Which will work physically Co located in the same place for the duration of the project.
We expect to have proposals coming not only from industry, not only from academia and from both sides.
Because we think that there might be good sources for problems in both on both sides.
This this problem should be researched because otherwise Pascal would not be the right place to carry them out and should have some software deliverable.
There's an emphasis on this being applied research and on having software output that then can be the basis for possibly the deployment of a commercial product.
There should have a training component incorporated.
And since whenever there is something with some commercial value, intellectual property issues cannot be just ignored.
There will be ways to minimize the hover overhead for people to manage these intellectual property issues by means of template agreements.
The industrial partners for these projects will come from pool of.
Industry of industries who expressed their interests in Pascal in general, which currently is up to, well, actually.
14 companies and organizations and hopefully will grow.
So why the harvest program?
I think that the slides from John and and Steve and all the presentations until now convinced you that Pascal was very successful in.
In terms of scientific outputs and in shaping the scientific community and machine learning, but it could have been more effective in interacting with the outside world, I mean.
Seen from the Galaxy of industry or from other disciplines, there's a lot of dark energy in in Pascal that should be brought to irradiate a bit more, probably.
That's another reason that is that many research results.
Developed within Pascal and in the machine learning community.
Could have commercial applications, but as a matter of fact they did not receive the correct exposure for them to be.
Turning to commercial applications and last but not least, even though probably to this audience, this doesn't speak too much.
There's something called open innovation that is.
Popular buzzword these years in.
Company environments that makes that there is more openness to conduct.

Joint research with academia open innovation is also about a lot of other things, but one of the components is about collaboration with academia and probably this makes that this is the right time for attempting this activity.
So as I mentioned, we want.

Harvest projects to be both research and also to have real application interest the way that we think we can achieve this is by basically imposing that the teams carrying out projects be mixed with at least 1/3 of the components coming from industry and 1/3 of the components coming from academia or public research.
Just because in this way there will be a kind of automatic filtering of the subjects.
Um?
Another thing which is important is that there will be.
Clear expected deliverables for the projects in terms of some.
Software package which doesn't need to be anything close to fully fledged product.
It can and it will in general only be a proof of concept prototype, but still it will be sufficient.
It will be a sufficient starting point for sale.
Commercial partner to proceed to development.
If the prototype is successful and is of any interest which is not guaranteed.

Permit to do anything else.

As I mentioned, participants will be working physically Co located on one side, so the expectation is that some of the partners will be traveling and spending some time away from their usual place of residence.
So Pascal will cover these expenses but will not cover salaries.
From any of the participants.
This also means that there is an investment which is made on both sides, because both sides must make available resources for a certain amount of time.

And also the fact that there is some even short-term relocation implies that participants have some significant personal investment in the project and so they will be strongly motivated or of making a success of the project.
Finally, we think that the effect of being physically collocated and working on something involving software development is also very useful because.
I cannot think of any more effective way of exchanging experience than actually working on a project with the best experts, either industrial or academic on a project.
So, and this will be coupled with specific training activities, kind of more traditional formal training activities, so I was listening people saying that in summer schools on the boot camp.

The students very much appreciated the practical work that was done and ask for more if you want for some participants who might well be PhD students, or even maybe massive students, these would kind of be the father of all practicals, so.

To be around 3 months.

But obviously we don't expect people just to.
Show up there an.
Come up with an idea and start working in three months afterwards.
Everything is done.

I would imagine that sometime around.

And around five months before the project, then fully fledged proposal is submitted fully fledged doesn't mean long and heavy.

Now.
Maybe some of you will be more serious than me and will do five or six, but I don't expect anything near the proposal that, for instance, you have.
We have to submit to the European Commission for.
Anne.
Many people would.
